titre_video: Enzo r√©cup√®re le marc de caf√© pour les plantes #autisme #autiste #tsa #shorts
description:
Enzo c'est mon petit fr√®re. Il est autiste s√©v√®re avec d√©ficience intellectuelle associ√©e. Il a appris √† g√©rer les stimulations ext√©rieures avec l'ABA: le bruit, la lumi√®re et maintenant on peut l'emmener presque partout et il adore!!!
Le handicap invisible comme le sien, correctement pris en charge, permet une r√©elle inclusion dans la soci√©t√© et mon fr√®re en est bien la preuve.
Enzo ne sera jamais totalement autonome. On ne peut pas le laisser en autonomie totale ou sans aucune surveillance. Il prend donc l‚Äôattention et l‚Äô√©nergie d‚Äôau moins une personne. Mes parents ont mis en place des apprentissages afin qu‚Äôil gagne le maximum d‚Äôautonomie √† la hauteur de ses capacit√©s. √âgalement le but est qu‚Äôil puisse participer √† la vie de la famille √† la maison et le travail qui va avec. Il peut √©tendre le linge, le ramasser, remplir le lave linge, remplir le lave-vaisselle, vider celui-ci, couper des l√©gumes en cuisine ou encore comme ici r√©cup√©rer le marc de caf√© pour les plantes du jardin! √áa demande de la motricit√© fine pour Enzo de tenir une petite capsule et la vider avec une cuill√®re. Ensuite il doit trier le caf√© d‚Äôun cot√©, les capsules vides‚Ä¶ et ne pas les rem√©langer avec les pleines üòÖ Cela demande beaucoup de temps pour qu‚Äôil maitrise un apprentissage et qu‚Äôil soit de moins en moins surveiller. Ce qui permet de d√©gager du temps √† la personne qui le g√®re pour faire autre chose en m√™me temps. Enzo est tr√®s souvent avec quelqu‚Äôun, ce qui peut le rendre d√©pendant d‚Äô√™tre toujours accroch√© √† un aidant. Le marc de caf√© participe √† lui apprendre √† √™tre seul. Patience et rigueur sont des ma√Ætres mots avec mon petit fr√®re ü•πü•∞
Au quotidien, il nous apprend qu'il en faut peu pour √™tre heureux.
Si tu veux en apprendre plus sur l'autisme ou la joie de vivre avec nous abonne toi √† nos diff√©rents r√©seaux sociaux:  @Enzoetcharlotte  !

titre_video: Freedom - What does it really mean?
description:
Freedom, at its core, is the ability to act, think, and live without undue restriction or control. It is one of the most fundamental desires of human beings, encompassing the autonomy to make choices, express oneself, and pursue personal fulfilment. On a personal level, freedom means having the space and permission to be who we are authentically, without fear of judgment or external imposition. It allows individuals to explore their potential, pursue their passions, and cultivate a sense of purpose.

However, true freedom is not simply about the absence of constraints; it also comes with responsibility. It requires the understanding that one‚Äôs freedom should not infringe on the rights and freedoms of others. It also implies the capacity to manage the consequences of one‚Äôs choices and actions, emphasizing the balance between independence and interconnectedness in human societies.

In essence, freedom is not just a political or social condition; it is a state of mind. For many, it involves breaking free from internal limitations like fear, self-doubt, or societal expectations. Real freedom, then, is the ability to live in alignment with one‚Äôs values, to connect meaningfully with others, and to find inner peace, regardless of external circumstances.

titre_video: The Power of Perversity  How Being Unpredictable Boosts Autonomy
description:
Welcome to "The Power of Perversity: How Being Unpredictable Boosts Autonomy," an intriguing YouTube series exploring the paradoxical nature of human behavior and its impact on personal autonomy and empowerment. Join us as we delve into the fascinating concept of perversity‚Äîthe deliberate deviation from expectations‚Äîand discover how embracing unpredictability can lead to greater freedom, creativity, and self-determination.

Human beings are complex and multifaceted creatures, often defying logic and convention in pursuit of autonomy and self-expression. In this series, we explore the concept of perversity as a means of asserting individuality and reclaiming agency in a world that seeks to impose conformity and control.

Through thought-provoking discussions, real-life examples, and expert insights, we examine the psychological mechanisms underlying perversity and its role in fostering resilience, innovation, and personal growth. From small acts of rebellion to radical acts of defiance, we explore how embracing unpredictability can empower individuals to break free from societal norms and chart their own course in life.

One of the most intriguing aspects we explore is the idea that embracing perversity can serve as a form of self-liberation and resistance against oppressive systems. By refusing to conform to external expectations and challenging the status quo, individuals can reclaim their autonomy and assert their agency in shaping their own destinies.

Furthermore, we delve into the benefits of embracing unpredictability in various aspects of life, from personal relationships and career choices to creative pursuits and self-expression. By embracing spontaneity, experimentation, and risk-taking, individuals can unlock new possibilities, expand their horizons, and cultivate a sense of freedom and self-mastery.

But embracing perversity is not without its challenges and risks. We explore the potential pitfalls of being unpredictable, including social ostracism, rejection, and misunderstanding. However, we also highlight the rewards of staying true to oneself and following one's own path, even in the face of adversity.

Through inspiring stories, practical tips, and thought-provoking exercises, we empower viewers to embrace their perversity and cultivate a sense of autonomy and authenticity in their lives. Whether you're seeking to break free from societal expectations, pursue your passions, or assert your individuality, "The Power of Perversity" offers valuable insights and guidance to help you navigate the complexities of human behavior and embrace the power of being unpredictable.

In conclusion, "The Power of Perversity: How Being Unpredictable Boosts Autonomy" invites viewers to embrace the paradoxes of human nature and celebrate the liberating potential of embracing unpredictability.

titre_video: Ils ont choisi une vie simple, loin du syst√®me
Ma vie face √† la solitude | RTS
description:
Une vie de solitude‚ÄØ 

Savez-vous qu‚Äôen Suisse, plus d‚Äôun tiers des foyers est constitu√© d‚Äôune seule personne ? Personnes √¢g√©es, jeunes, naufrag√©s sentimentaux, timides, divorc√©s, pr√©caires, la solitude est ainsi la fid√®le compagne de millions d‚Äôentre nous.‚ÄØ 
Mais il arrive aussi que ces solitaires aient tout simplement choisi de le rester. Par go√ªt de la libert√©, par choix, parce que cela comble toutes leurs attentes. Ils sont, disons-le, une minorit√©. Les solitaires qui ont accept√© de t√©moigner dans ce reportage sign√© Sabine Pirolt et Nicolas Pallay expriment une grande souffrance. Pas seulement celle de passer No√´l tout seul, devant son bloc de foie gras et la t√©l√©vision. Mais aussi, en termes d‚Äôestime de soi, ou d‚Äôexclusion sociale.‚ÄØ 
Mais les solitaires se rebiffent et tentent de r√©sister, vous allez le voir. Dans ce reportage vous allez d√©couvrir, par exemple, comment √† Zurich on commence √† imaginer des appartements collectifs, o√π chacun peut conserver son intimit√©, dans un espace partag√©. Tr√®s int√©ressant. Vous allez voir aussi des agences de voyage d‚Äôun type nouveau. Car la solitude, c‚Äôest d√©sormais aussi un gros march√©. 
Quelques nouvelles encore de nos interlocuteurs. Ainsi, juste apr√®s notre tournage, St√©phanie, √† qui la tendresse d‚Äôun homme manquait beaucoup, a rencontr√© quelqu‚Äôun et vit une tr√®s belle histoire d‚Äôamour. Doroth√©e, la jeune m√®re de famille qui vit avec 2000 francs par mois, a commenc√© une formation de fleuriste, son r√™ve de toujours. Enfin, Rafaele, le jeune informaticien, a quitt√© l‚Äôappartement de ses parents et travaille √† Zurich o√π il a d√©m√©nag√©. On lui souhaite de se faire rapidement des amis, et qui sait, trouver l‚Äôamour.‚ÄØ

titre_video: Slug reduction without pellets and barriers
description:
In damp climates especially, slugs and snails are always present. Just in dry weather, you don't see them very much. Then as soon as it rains a little, they reappear to eat!

You cannot prevent this process, but you can reduce the number of slugs and snails which keep appearing. You do not need to use slug pellets or nematodes.

I show you some of my solutions which include removal of older and lower leaves from plants, removing wooden sides of beds if they are old and rotting, keeping edges tidy, and no dig method herself.

No dig allows soil ecology to flourish. That includes ground beetles and toads, which eat slugs and slug eggs.

Learn more in many of my other videos such as this one https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nbf7D80j5os

Also in my books, and on my website https://charlesdowding.co.uk

You can join this channel by paying a monthly fee, to support our work with helping gardeners grow better, and to receive monthly videos made only for members:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCB1J6siDdmhwah7q0O2WJBg/join

titre_video: Organic Farming
description:
Organic farming is a sustainable agricultural practice that relies on natural processes and materials to grow crops and raise livestock. It avoids the use of synthetic fertilizers, pesticides, genetically modified organisms (GMOs), and growth hormones. Instead, organic farming emphasizes:

Soil health: Techniques like crop rotation, composting, and green manuring help maintain and improve soil fertility and structure.

Natural pest control: Encourages the use of beneficial insects, biological pest control methods, and companion planting to manage pests.

Biodiversity: Promotes a diverse ecosystem by planting a variety of crops and creating habitats for wildlife.

Animal welfare: Ensures that animals are raised in humane conditions with access to pasture and organic feed.

titre_video: How Climate Change Is Impacting Honey Production #Shorts
description:
Honeybees are traveling farther to search for nectar because of climate change ‚Äî here‚Äôs why that matters.
¬ª Sign up for our newsletter KnowThis to get the biggest stories of the day delivered straight to your inbox: https://go.nowth.is/knowthis_youtube
¬ª Subscribe to NowThis Earth: https://go.nowth.is/Earth_Subscribe

In partnership with Eat Forum, the Stockholm Resilience Centre, and the IKEA Foundation.

Climate change is impacting honeybees, flower development, and honey production altogether. The climate affects the nectar and pollen production of flowers. Some species of flowers are even dying off because of rising temperatures, droughts, and increasing pests that thrive in warmer weather. This is limiting where honeybees can travel to collect nectar and thus make honey. For biodiversity such as bees to thrive, the EAT-Lancet commission recommends setting aside at least 10% of farmland for conservation so that biodiversity can thrive.

titre_video: Bats are power pollinators!
description:
Hundreds of species of economically and/or ecologically important plants rely primarily on bats for pollination or seed dispersal, sometimes both.

Some examples of these include agave (tequila and mescal!), bananas, durian, mangrove, calabash, various palm trees, kapok, piper, eucalyptus, baobab, African butter and tallow tree, bottle brush, and many giant cacti including saguaro and organ pipe.

Many tropical and sub-tropical rainforest ecosystems also rely on bat seed dispersers to regenerate areas of habitat loss.

Insect eating bats not only protect humans by eating crop and yard pests but they protect all of us, including other pollinators, by reducing the need for more pesticides. 


Visit MerlinTuttle.org to learn more about bats, why we need them and how you can help. 
Merlin Tuttle‚Äôs Bat Conservation (MTBC) was founded by Dr. Merlin Tuttle. He has studied and photographed bats worldwide for more than 60 years. He founded and led Bat Conservation International (BCI) for 30 years, then left BCI in 2009 and founded MTBC. Join at www.MerlinTuttle.org!

Merlin‚Äôs unique photography and communication first led to global appreciation of bats as safe, invaluable, even cute, and likable. No one has better demonstrated the power of combining captivating photos with sound science to win friends instead of battles for bats. Nor has anyone better demonstrated how conservation can benefit humans. Merlin‚Äôs legendary photos and experience provide invaluable guidance and inspiration that must be preserved and shared for future generations.

MTBC is now Merlin‚Äôs sole source of support, both for his ongoing conservation efforts and for preservation of his priceless photo collection and legacy resources.

Edited and Directed by Hugo Vargas-Zesati
Copyright 2018 ¬© MerlinTuttle.org All Rights Reserved

Music : Mozart, The Marriage of Figaro

titre_video: Mason Bees & Bee Haven Homes | Early Pollinators
description:
New Arrival: Mason Bees + Bee Haven Homes üêù Mason Bees great for early pollinating...and they're non-aggressive, so they're the perfect addition to your yard!

We store the Mason Bees in a refrigerated environment (keeping them dormant), until they are taken home by you and left outside undercover. All you have to do is open the box, place the open box within the Bee Haven and wait.

They'll soon come out and eventually nesting in the tubes...and eventually pollinate your garden. Since they are solitary creatures and feel they have nothing to protect, they are considered non-aggressive.

titre_video: Never pay for worms again, worm grunting #cabin #fishing #worms #fisherman #homestead #diy
description: Living alone in the woods, you learn unique skills. This is the best way to catch worms for fishing, compost, etc. BUT worm grunting will also bring up native and invasive species, specifically the huge and snake like asian jumping worm. These ones actually over consume organic matter in natural habitats, such as leaf litter and healthy root systems, and churn out low quality soil that contributes to erosion. I've been doing this to get rid of as many of that worm type as possible because my Appalachian soil, already rocky, struggles to provide appropriate nutrients for my garden and the erosion on my land has become a major problem.

titre_video: How does an earthworm eat?
description:
An earthworm is a terrestrial invertebrate that belongs to the phylum Annelida. They exhibit a tube-within-a-tube body plan; they are externally segmented with corresponding internal segmentation; and they usually have setae on all segments. They occur worldwide where soil, water, and temperature allow.

Earthworms are commonly found in soil, eating a wide variety of organic matter. This organic matter includes plant matter, living protozoa, rotifers, nematodes, bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms. An earthworm's digestive system runs the length of its body.

An earthworm respires (breathes) through its skin. It has a double transport system made of coelomic fluid that moves within the fluid-filled coelom and a simple, closed circulatory system.

titre_video: Natural Habitat Shorts- ‚≠êÔ∏ènosed moles are virtually blind, but their noses mirror human sightüëÉüëÄ

description:
Bonjour les amis, nous voil√† √† la cinqui√®me √©tape de la construction de notre poulailler r√©alis√© √† partir d'une cuve IBC de 1000 litres. Aujourd'hui, on aborde une petite erreur que nous avons commise : les battants de porte ont √©t√© con√ßus de la m√™me taille. Dans cette vid√©o, nous allons discuter de l'importance de cr√©er des portes avec des proportions de 1/3 et 2/3, ce qui facilitera grandement le nettoyage et l'acc√®s au poulailler. 

Tout dans notre construction est minutieusement ajust√©, √©liminant tout espace entre la cuve et les ouvertures. Nous avons √©galement remplac√© le socle d'origine, en fer et plastique noir (ou en palette sur certaines cuves), par un socle en bois de 7 cm de section, soigneusement lasur√© et taill√© aux bonnes dimensions. 

Il ne reste plus qu'√† installer le toit et √† ajouter une a√©ration √† la place du bouchon rouge au sommet de la cuve. Ces deux √©l√©ments viendront compl√©ter notre poulailler de mani√®re fonctionnelle. 

Cette vid√©o offre un aper√ßu d√©taill√© de tout le processus de construction, d√©montrant qu'il n'est pas compliqu√© de transformer une cuve de 1000 litres en un poulailler fonctionnel. Cependant, la cl√© r√©side dans la pr√©cision de l'ajustement des ouvrants et des a√©rations. L'outil essentiel dont vous aurez besoin est la scie sauteuse, et pour un travail optimal, une scie √† onglet √©lectrique est fortement recommand√©e.

titre_video: Have You Tried AMP Grazing or Other Regenerative Agricultural Practices?
description:
How we treat our soils is directly connected to the health of our animals, our food, and our land. We know cows are a good tool for regenerating soils when we allow them to graze in one herd, eat half the forage and trample the rest (spreading their manure evenly) and then moving on to the next small pasture, letting the previous piece of land rest.  These quick moves let most of the farm rest, most of the time. 

What do we call this method of raising cattle that makes soil more productive without fertilizer, allows farmers to support their families with more money and less work, and gives habitats to quail and other wild birds? 

AMP grazing. There are a few definitions of AMP grazing out there‚Ä¶ 

Here‚Äôs how we define it: 

Adaptive Multi-Paddock (AMP) grazing mimics how bison helped create 15 foot deep topsoils on the great plains. The bison would eat only half the forage and then stomp the rest covering the soil and their manure would get evenly spread - a natural fertilizer - then the magic happens. 

As the herd moves on, the land is left to rest. It is this heavy hit and rest that allows the native plants to flourish - sucking down carbon and keeping soil microbes cool while they do the hard work.

AMP farmers mimic this rest period by shifting cattle between paddocks more often; giving their cattle fresh grass daily and their fields time to regenerate. 

The next stop in our roadshow is Telluride, CO, on August 21! Join us at the Sheridan Opera House on August 21 at 5:30p - Q&A with director Peter Byck follows the screening.   @mountainfilm

#regenerativefarming #regenerativeagriculture #regenerativeag #regenerativefarm #regenerativeagriculturemovement #carbonnation #rootssodeep #USDA #farmers #farming

titre_video: Roots So Deep (you can see the devil down there) premieres THIS WEEK!  #regenerativeagriculture
description:
Roots So Deep (you can see the devil down there) premieres for streaming in the US and Canada THIS WEEK! Watch all four episodes NOW - check our bio!

A Groundbreaking Research Project 10 years in the making

P‚Äã‚Äãeter Byck helped to lead a $10 million research project comparing Adaptive Multi-Paddock (AMP) grazing with conventional grazing focused on soil health &  soil carbon storage, microbial/bug/bird biodiversity, water cycling, greenhouse gas cycling and much more.

Roots So Deep (you can see the devil down there) is a 4-part documentary series about inventive farmers
and maverick scientists building a path to solving climate change with hooves, heart and soil. Can an
underutilized way to graze cattle, that mimics the way bison once roamed the land, help get farmers out
of debt, restore our depleted soils, rebuild wildlife habitat and draw down huge amounts of carbon?
Cattle have been seen as eco-villains for a long time. What if they can be heroes instead?

‚ÄúRoots So Deep‚Äù is guided by director and wrangler of scientists Peter Byck as he meets farmers on both
sides of the fence ‚Äì the folks practicing an adaptive way to graze, and their neighbors set in their family‚Äôs
generations-old method of doing things. Byck‚Äôs team of scientists are measuring what‚Äôs happening on
both sides of the fences ‚Äì exploring if this adaptive grazing could help slow down climate change.
And one question looms over the whole series: even if the science shows that the adaptive way to graze
is better for the land and the farmers‚Äô pocket books, will the old school farmers change, will they adopt a different method?

SAFETY NOTE - we‚Äôve already seen fake links / scams / phishing attempts pretending to offer a download of the series. Be careful! The only safe way to watch is streaming through our website!

INTERNATIONAL PREMIERES:
UK + Ireland - June 26th
South Africa - July 21st
More to come!

titre_video: Anth√©nea : la maison pour vivre sur l‚Äôeau
description:
Ce ¬´ n√©nuphar ¬ª high-tech inspir√© de ¬´ James Bond ¬ª pourrait √™tre l‚Äôhabitat flottant de demain. Mobile, √©colo et donc futuriste. Invent√© en Bretagne, il s√©duit d√©j√† certains groupes h√¥teliers.

C‚Äôest une capsule dod√©cagonale, recouverte d‚Äôun d√¥me. Elle est class√©e en tant que bateau (de cat√©gorie C) mais s‚Äôapparente surtout √† un loft paisiblement nomade. Imagin√© par Jean-Michel Ducancelle, architecte naval et navigateur, Anth√©nea est le fruit de son coup de foudre pour la pieuvre m√©canique dans ¬´ L‚Äôespion qui m‚Äôaimait ¬ª mais s‚Äôinspire aussi de la c√©l√®bre villa bulle de Cardin (√† laquelle Jean-Michel Ducancelle a particip√©).

La prouesse d‚ÄôAnth√©nea, c‚Äôest son impact nul sur la faune et la flore marines ainsi que la myriade de d√©tails qui en font un ovni quasi parfait pour tous ceux qui souhaitent embrasser un style de vie aquatique solidement tourn√© vers le futur. Cette soucoupe flottante est ronde comme une m√©duse car c‚Äôest la forme optimale de r√©sistance √† des conditions extr√™mes de vie sur l‚Äôeau et cela augmente sa stabilit√© et sa portance. Son inventeur assure qu‚ÄôAnth√©nea est insubmersible, avec un envahissement au maximum √† hauteur des genoux en cas de br√®che majeure.

L‚Äôint√©rieur est sph√©rique et √©pur√©, √† l‚Äôimage d‚Äôun coquillage. Sous la coupole s‚Äôoffre un espace vital et vitr√© sur 360 degr√©s. Le canap√©, plac√© face aux parois transparentes immerg√©es, est un astucieux observatoire sous-marin. Les voisins les plus proches sont donc les poissons. D√©j√†, des groupes h√¥teliers ont pass√© commande pour des eaux tropicales (Four Seasons Maldives, dit-on) d‚Äôun ensemble de mod√®les non navigables. Comptez entre 800 et 2 000 euros la nuit.

titre_video: Smoked Salmon Bites #wastefree #recipeoftheday #holidayrecipes
description:
Hosting a holiday gathering? üéäü™© Keep it simple and delicious with these Smoked Salmon Bites. 

Quick to make, delightful to eat, and zero waste ‚Äì just how we like it here at FoodCycler. üíö

Smoked Salmon Bites

1 sheet frozen puff pastry, thawed
2-3 Tbps chives, chopped
2 Tbsp spicy mustard
1 Tbsp mayonnaise
1 Tbsp red wine vinegar
1/4 cup olive oil
3/4 cup Fresh arugula, chopped
4 oz smoked salmon
1/3 cup Asiago cheese, finely grated

Cut pastry sheet into 25 squares, bake for 12-14 minutes at 400¬∞F. Combine mustard, mayonnaise, vinegar, oil, and chives. Spoon onto each pastry square. Top with smoked salmon, arugula, and cheese. Enjoy!

titre_video: Components of an Ecosystem (Our Environment) (Science) Class 10
Le compost √ßa attire les mouches, les rats, les fourmis... c'est un nid √† nuisibles
description:
Composter, c'est bien beau, mais √ßa attire les mouches, les fourmis et m√™me les souris ou les rats ! üò† C'est un vrai nid √† nuisibles ! üêÄü¶üüêú

Hep, hep, hep ! Ne tirons pas de conclusions h√¢tives ! Le composteur peut devenir un lieu de vie pour divers insectes, petits mammif√®res et m√™me quelques reptiles, mais il ne faut pas s‚Äôalarmer. En r√©alit√© :

1. Tous ne sont pas des nuisibles :
Ces petits visiteurs sont en fait des alli√©s naturels du compostage. Les larves, vers de terre, et autres d√©composeurs jouent un r√¥le crucial dans la transformation des v√©g√©taux en compost riche et fertile.

2. Un compost bien entretenu √©loigne les v√©ritables nuisibles :
Les mouches et souris ne nuisent pas directement au processus de compostage, mais pour √©viter qu‚Äôils ne se multiplient trop, voici quelques bonnes pratiques :

‚Ä¢ Brasser r√©guli√®rement le compost : L'a√©ration perturbe les zones chaudes qui attirent les souris et les insectes. Un compost bien m√©lang√© est moins accueillant pour ces squatteurs.
‚Ä¢ √âviter les restes alimentaires comme la viande : Ces d√©chets attirent les nuisibles et transforment ton composteur en restaurant cinq √©toiles ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê.
‚Ä¢ Maintenir une bonne humidit√© : Pendant les p√©riodes s√®ches, arrose l√©g√®rement ton compost pour √©loigner les fourmis et les rongeurs. Cependant, veille √† ne pas le rendre trop humide pour √©viter les moucherons.
‚Ä¢ Limiter l'acc√®s : Utilise un couvercle sur ton composteur et installe un grillage fin au fond pour emp√™cher les rongeurs d‚Äôy p√©n√©trer.
‚Ä¢ √âquilibrer les mati√®res : Ajoute de la mati√®re s√®che, comme des feuilles mortes, pour √©quilibrer les d√©chets verts. Cela rend le compost moins attrayant pour les nuisibles.

En adoptant ces quelques astuces, tu pourras profiter d'un compostage efficace sans les d√©sagr√©ments li√©s aux nuisibles.
Alors, pr√™t √† composter sereinement ? üôåüå±

titre_video: waste decomposer I agriculture purpose use#waste decomposer
Difference between producer and decomposer | Ecology | NCERT #education #ncert
description:
Difference between Producers and decomposer 

Producers:-
1. They are plants. 
2.  Producers are autotrophs. 
3. They utilise inorganic nutrients.
4. Producers provide food to all other organisms.
5. They belong to first trophic level.

Decomposer:
1. They are microorganisms.
2. They are heterotrophs.
3. They liberate inorganic nutrients.
4. Decomposers dispose off organic remains.
5. They belong to last trophic level, 5th or 6th.

üåê The Big Picture: Food Web üåê
We've talked about individual food chains, but how do they all fit together? In this episode, we unravel the intricacies of a food web‚Äîan interconnected network where energy flows in complex ways, from the sun ‚òÄÔ∏è to producers üå±, to consumers ü¶ìü¶Å, and finally to decomposers üçÇ.

ü¶ó The Domino Effect üé≤
Remember the grasshoppers? Their extinction wouldn't just be bad news for them. The ripple effects would touch every corner of the ecosystem, affecting both direct and indirect dependents. üåæüö´üê∏ü¶â

üîó Interconnected Lives üîó
In a food web, the extinction of a single species can have a profound impact, highlighting the delicate balance and interdependencies that exist in our ecosystems. üå≥üíîü¶ä

titre_video: Comment faire les choux simplement et d√©licieux ? #cuisine #astuce #recette #asiatique
Mediterranean Bowls | Mediterranean Diet Recipes! #mediterraneandiet
description:
The Mediterranean Diet helped me lose 31 pounds! Eating the Mediterranean way with recipes like this healthy Mediterranean bowl naturally helped me lose weight when I unintentionally gained it. I always say eating the Mediterranean way is NOW a diet... It's a lifestyle! #mediterraneandiet #looseweight #howtolooseweight 

If you want to follow the Mediterranean Diet, check out my 30 day meal plan HERE: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLNLLLtGyGf0DrTUAR3xQl7WseB06Eh2kl&si=otS9Yi_RunHncv6o 

Make these Mediterranean Bowls: 
‚ñ¢1 cup tri-color quinoa, rinsed
‚ñ¢Kosher salt
‚ñ¢1 ¬Ω cups hummus
‚ñ¢Mediterranean Cucumber Tomato Salad
‚ñ¢4 to 6 ounces feta cheese, broken into large pieces
‚ñ¢¬Ω cup pitted Kalamata olives
‚ñ¢¬Ω cup pitted Castelvetrano olives
‚ñ¢Harissa (optional)
‚ñ¢1 cup quartered marinated artichoke hearts
‚ñ¢Extra virgin olive oil
‚ñ¢Aleppo pepper and/or sumac (optional)

1. Cook the quinoa. In a large saucepan, combine the quinoa with 1 ¬æ cups of water and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat. Cover and let simmer for about 15 minutes, or until the quinoa has doubled in size and absorbed the water. Turn the heat off and let the quinoa sit, covered, for another 10 minutes while you work on other things. Fluff with a fork before using.
2. Assemble the Mediterranean bowls. Using 6 shallow dinner bowls, begin dividing the hummus in the middle (about 2 large spoonfuls per bowl). Divide the quinoa and the salad on either side of the hummus. Fill the gaps with the feta cheese, olives, a spoonful of harissa (if using), and marinated artichoke hearts.
3. Finish and serve. Drizzle a little olive oil over the hummus and wherever else you like. And if you like, sprinkle on Aleppo pepper and/or sumac to season. Enjoy immediately.

titre_video: Why Bees Are Earth's Tiny Heroes!
description:

titre_video: Zero Waste Zucchini Bread
description:
Who‚Äôs ready for zucchini bread? üçû While we‚Äôre baking, we‚Äôre also tossing kitchen scraps‚Äîincluding paper towels‚Äîright into the FoodCycler! üåø It‚Äôs perfect for taking care of the cleanup while you bake, reducing food waste volume by up to 90%, and making plant food all at the same time! üôå

Follow us for more easy recipes and zero waste tips! üå±

Zucchini Bread Recipe

Ingredients:
1 & 3/4 cups (220g) all-purpose flour
2 tsp ground cinnamon
1 tsp baking soda
1/2 tsp salt
1/2 cup (125ml) vegetable oil
1 cup (200g) granulated sugar
2 large eggs
1 tsp vanilla extract
1 medium (about 2 cups) grated zucchini

Instructions:
Preheat oven to 350¬∞F and grease a 9√ó5‚Ä≥ loaf pan. In one bowl, mix flour, cinnamon, baking soda, and salt. In another, whisk oil, sugar, eggs, and vanilla, then stir in grated zucchini. Combine the wet and dry mixtures, stir until just combined, and pour into the pan. Bake for 60-65 minutes or until a toothpick comes out clean. Enjoy!

titre_video: Dropping a match into liquid oxygen
description:
So today, I'm going to be making some liquid oxygen. Oxygen is normally a gas, but it can be turned into a liquid using liquid nitrogen. It's a bit hard to see, but liquid oxygen is faintly blue. This is very dangerous, but what's fun to do, is to throw a match into it. As a liquid, oxygen is an even more powerful oxidizer and it can sometimes react explosively.

Recently, the Finance Minister of India, presenting the interim budget announced the expansion of the application of Nano DAP on various crops in all agro climatic zones.

What is the use of IFFCO Sagarika fertilizer?
Target crops

Sagarika is a broad-spectrum bio stimulant which can be applied to a wide range of crops such as (but not limited to): Commercial Crops: Cotton, Jute, Sugarcane, Cumin, etc. Field Crops: Rice, Wheat, Sorghum (Jowar), Bajra, etc. Plantations: Arecanut, Coconut, Coffee, Rubber, Tea, Mulberry, Cocoa, etc.


What are the benefits of nano urea fertilizer?
Nano Urea is cost-effective and required in low quantities. The most critical benefit of using Nano Urea for agriculture is its minimal impact on the environment. This will result in reducing the release of greenhouse gasses and improve the quality of air and water.

How much nano urea per Litre?
2-4 ml
Nano Urea contains 4.0 % total nitrogen (w/v). Mix 2-4 ml of Nano urea (4 % N) in one Litre of water and spray on crop leaves at its active growth stages.

What is the difference between DAP and nano DAP?
It is a source of nitrogen and phosphorus ‚Äì 2 key primary nutrients essential for the growth of crops. It contains 8% Nitrogen and 16% Phosphorus by volume. Unlike conventional DAP, which comes in granular form, IFFCO's Nano DAP is in liquid form.

Advantages of NANO DAP
o Higher Crop Yield: Due to small size and more surface area to volume ratio; seed treatment and foliar application of Nano DAP at critical growth stages enhances nutrient availability to crops.Hence, Crop yield increases due to increase in leaf chlorophyll, photosynthesis, root biomass, number of effective tillers and branches.

o Quality Food: Nutritional quality of harvested food produce was found to be better in terms of protein and nutrient content.

o Reduction in Chemical Fertilizer Usage: Enhanced use efficiency of one bottle (500 ml) of Nano DAP can potentially replace the phosphorus requirement met by conventional DAP by 50%.

o Environment Friendly: Production of Nano DAP is energy and resource friendly. Precision and targeted application of this to crops therefore leads to agriculture sustainability and safety of the environment by reducing soil, air and water pollution.

o It is more pocket-friendly than its conventional counterpart.A 500 ml bottle of Nano DAP, equivalent to a 50-kg bag of conventional DAP

o It is set to significantly reduce this import burden.

What is DAP?
o DAP, or di-ammonium phosphate, is the second most commonly used fertilizers in India after urea.

o It is high in phosphorus (P) that stimulates root establishment and development ‚Äî without which plants cannot grow to their normal size, or will take too long to mature. 

Q1:What is Nitrogen?
It is the most abundant element in our atmosphere, is crucial to life. Nitrogen is found in soils and plants, in the water we drink, and in the air we breathe. It is also essential to life: a key building block of DNA, which determines our genetics, is essential to plant growth, and therefore necessary for the food we grow.

#shivanandachakari

titre_video: Sustainable Pulp Coffee Trays: Eco-Friendly Production, Features & Applications
description:
For more details, please refer to our website or contact us directly.
https://www.eggtraysmachine.com
whatsapp:0086 13503722234
Email: lily@agicogroup.com
Pulp coffee trays (also known as pulp coffee coasters or holders) are eco-friendly products typically made from recycled pulp or plant fibers (such as bagasse, bamboo pulp, etc.). They are designed to hold coffee cups, providing heat insulation, anti-slip properties, and decorative functions. Below is a detailed breakdown of their production process, features, and applications.
I. Production Process
Raw Material Preparation

Primary materials: Recycled paper pulp, bagasse, bamboo fiber, wheat straw, and other natural fibers.

Additives: Food-grade waterproof coatings (e.g., PE or biodegradable PLA), optional dyes.

Pulp Molding

Raw materials are crushed, mixed with water, and processed into a pulp slurry, then pressed into shape (round, square, or custom designs) using molds.

Custom textures, brand logos, or patterns can be embossed.

Drying & Curing

High-temperature drying removes moisture and enhances rigidity.

Some products undergo surface coating (e.g., biodegradable PLA) for water resistance.

Post-Processing

Trimming excess edges, quality inspection, and sterilization (food-contact products must meet safety standards).

Printing designs or branding (using eco-friendly inks).
II. Product Features
Eco-Friendliness

Biodegradable or compostable, reducing plastic pollution (compliant with standards like EU EN13432).

Significantly lower carbon footprint compared to plastic or foam alternatives.

Functionality

Heat Insulation: Protects surfaces from hot cups.

Anti-Slip: Textured surface improves grip, preventing spills.

Design Versatility

Customizable in color, shape, thickness (typically 1.5‚Äì3mm), and surface texture.

Ideal for branding (e.g., company logos, promotional slogans).
III. Applications
Food & Beverage Industry

Takeaway coffee coasters for caf√©s, bubble tea shops, and fast-food chains.

Upscale dining table decor, enhancing brand image.

Events & Exhibitions
IV. Market Advantages & Trends
Policy-Driven Demand: Global plastic bans (e.g., China‚Äôs "Plastic Restriction Order," EU Single-Use Plastics Directive) boost pulp-based alternatives.

Consumer Preference: Growing eco-awareness favors green packaging.

Innovation Trends:

Enhanced waterproofing (fluorine-free coatings).

Hybrid materials (e.g., coffee grounds blended with pulp).

Foldable designs for portability.

Promotional giveaways at corporate events or eco-conscious conferences.

Customized trays for weddings, parties, and themed gatherings.

Household & Office Use

Daily heat protection, complementing home aesthetics.

Sustainable office supplies for meeting rooms.
IV. Market Advantages & Trends
Policy-Driven Demand: Global plastic bans (e.g., China‚Äôs "Plastic Restriction Order," EU Single-Use Plastics Directive) boost pulp-based alternatives.

Consumer Preference: Growing eco-awareness favors green packaging.

Innovation Trends:

Enhanced waterproofing (fluorine-free coatings).

Hybrid materials (e.g., coffee grounds blended with pulp).

Foldable designs for portability.
V. Key Considerations
Cost: Slightly higher per unit than plastic trays, but bulk orders reduce expenses.

Storage: Keep in dry conditions to prevent moisture deformation.

Disposal: Classify as compostable or dry waste (varies by local regulations).
Pulp coffee trays are a sustainable and functional choice for businesses and individuals committed to environmental responsibility. For customization, consult specialized eco-packaging suppliers (e.g., for sizing, certifications).

titre_video: MON P√àRE S'EST VENG√â üòÇ ( c'est un gamin mdr )
la meilleure fa√ßon de composter #jardin #potager #potagerbio #recyclage  #compost #permaculture
Spring Feeding : Workers Spread Sheep Manure & Bacteria Mix into Orchard Trenches
description:
A Little Wisdom Helps You Become Smarter !

In the video, a tractor slowly moves through a quiet apple orchard, pulling a wagon loaded with a dark mixture of sheep manure and bacterial fertilizer. Behind it, three workers use shovels to scoop the organic blend from the wagon and drop it into long, narrow trenches dug earlier by a trenching machine. These trenches run neatly between rows of bare apple trees, still dormant in the early spring cold.
 
This process, called trench fertilization, targets the trees‚Äô root zones. By burying the manure-fertilizer mix directly into the soil, nutrients are delivered exactly where the roots will absorb them as the trees wake up for spring. Sheep manure enriches the soil with natural minerals, while bacterial fertilizer breaks down organic matter faster, boosting soil health. Together, they create a sustainable alternative to chemical fertilizers, reducing pollution and improving fruit quality.
 
The method is both efficient and precise. The trenching machine saves hours of manual digging, and filling the trenches immediately after ensures nutrients stay concentrated near the roots. For orchards, this means stronger trees, sweeter apples, and a healthier ecosystem‚Äîall while keeping farming practices eco-friendly.

Biochar! Soil Health & Climate Change
description:
Biochar, essentially charcoal produced from organic materials via pyrolysis. Pyrolysis a process where biomass is heated in the absence of oxygen. Biochar offers numerous benefits for garden soil and the environment:

1) Soil Structure Improvement: Biochar helps to improve soil structure by increasing pore space, which enhances water infiltration, aeration, and root penetration. This results in better drainage in heavy soils and increased water retention in sandy soils.

2) Nutrient Retention and Availability: Biochar has a high surface area and a negative charge, which allows it to attract and retain nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and micronutrients. This not only prevents nutrient leaching but also makes these nutrients more available to plants over time as they are slowly released from the biochar.

3) Microbial Activity Enhancement: Biochar provides a habitat for beneficial soil microbes, fungi, and bacteria. These microbes form symbiotic relationships with plant roots, aiding in nutrient uptake, disease suppression, and overall plant health.

4) pH Buffering: Biochar has a neutral pH, which helps to buffer soil pH and prevent extreme fluctuations. This is especially beneficial in acidic soils, where biochar can help raise pH levels, making the soil more suitable for a wider range of plants.

5) Carbon Sequestration: Biochar is a stable form of carbon that can remain in the soil for hundreds to thousands of years, effectively sequestering carbon and mitigating climate change by reducing atmospheric CO2 levels.

In summary, biochar offers a sustainable and environmentally friendly solution for improving soil quality, enhancing plant growth, and promoting overall ecosystem health in garden environments.

#biochar #soilhealth #gardening #organicgardening #sustainable #climatechange #regenerativeagriculture #compost #gardeningtips #carbonsequestration #growyourownfood #gardentherapy #gardenlife #permaculture #soil #gardenersworld #garden 
#sustainablegardening #ecofriendly

description:

üìú Video Description:
üå± Revitalize Degraded Lands through Regenerative Agriculture!regenerativeagriculture.wiki+3MDPI+3SpringerLink+3
In this short video, Aqua and Farm Life Chronicles delves into how regenerative agriculture practices can restore degraded lands, enhance soil health, and promote sustainable farming.
Benefits of Regenerative Agriculture in Land Restoration:
1. Soil Health Improvement:
Implementing regenerative practices increases soil organic matter and fertility, leading to healthier and more productive land. 
2. Erosion Control:
Techniques such as cover cropping and reduced tillage help prevent soil erosion, preserving topsoil and maintaining land integrity. 
3. Water Retention Enhancement:
Improved soil structure from regenerative methods enhances water infiltration and retention, making lands more resilient to drought conditions. 
4. Biodiversity Restoration:
Encouraging diverse plant species and integrating agroforestry supports the return of native flora and fauna, boosting ecosystem health. 
5. Carbon Sequestration:
Healthy soils act as carbon sinks, capturing atmospheric CO‚ÇÇ and mitigating climate change impacts.

Hands-On Harvest : Extracting Vitex Root from Rock Crevices for Bonsai Crafting
description:
A Little Wisdom Helps You Become Smarter !

In the video, a gardener retrieves a Vitex root system from a rocky crevice to create bonsai. Here's how to do it safely and effectively:
 
Access the Roots
 
Use a pry bar (45-60cm steel) to widen gaps in rocks. Avoid hammering‚Äîslow levering prevents root damage.
 
Wear grippy gloves to pull roots by hand, preserving their natural twists shaped by years of rock pressure.
 
Root Protection
 
Keep 30% of original soil attached. Brush gently with a soft-bristle tool to expose roots without breaking hair-thin feeders.
 
Wrap exposed roots in damp sphagnum moss immediately to prevent drying (critical within 20 minutes).
 
Post-Harvest Care
 
Soak roots in willow-infused water for 24hrs. Willow bark‚Äôs salicylic acid boosts root regrowth by 60%.
 
Plant in 70% pumice + 30% compost mix‚Äîfast drainage mimics rocky habitats.
 
Key Reminders:
 
Never harvest from protected areas.
 
Trim only ‚Öì of foliage after planting to balance moisture needs.
 
Rotate pot weekly for even sunlight exposure during recovery.
 
This method respects the plant‚Äôs natural history while adapting it for ornamental use.

titre_video: Why We Plant Crimson Clover at Ward‚Äôs Farm NJ
description:
We are an organic flower farm here at Ward‚Äôs Farm. One way we support sustainability in farming is with the use of cover crops.

üçÄ Not only is Crimson Clover absolutely beautiful (& perfect for your Spring photoshoots), it‚Äôs beneficial to the land!

üçÄ We use Crimson Clover as a cover crop during our ‚Äòoff‚Äô season to help repair soil and add nutrients back into the ground. Clover adds nitrogen to the soil without the need for any fertilizer. It provides the highest amount of nitrogen to the soil compared to other cover crops. Crimson Clover acts as a nutrient scavenger, bringing up nutrients from deeper in the soil.

üçÄ The clover is great for pollinators like our honey bees. It is an important source of nectar in the beginning of the warm weather season before our cut flowers start to bloom. The long length of the clover blooms produce ample amounts of sweet nectar.

üçÄ The root system of clover helps to stop soil erosion. It prevents nutrient runoff and allows greater amounts of precipitation to enter the soil. This helps to build the soils for future crops (like our flowers!)

üçÄ Crimson clover serves as a habitat for beneficial insects that prey on small pests. It is effective at suppressing weeds when planted in the fall.

üçÄ We are here to grow beautiful flowers for the community and that means working in harmony with nature!

#CrimsonClover #Clover #SpringFlowers #GroundCover #CoverCrop #SoilHealth

description:
Accueillir des abeilles durant la saison estivale pr√©sente de nombreux avantages. Voici quelques raisons pour lesquelles il peut √™tre b√©n√©fique d'avoir des "mouches √† miel" dans votre jardin :

1 - Les abeilles jouent un r√¥le essentiel dans la pollinisation des plantes. En √©t√©, de nombreuses plantes sont en fleurs et d√©pendent des abeilles pour transporter le pollen d'une fleur √† l'autre, favorisant ainsi la reproduction des plantes et le d√©veloppement des fruits.

2 - Si vous avez un jardin ou des cultures, la pr√©sence d'abeilles peut augmenter consid√©rablement la production. Les abeilles pollinisent les fleurs des l√©gumes, des fruits et des plantes √† fleurs, ce qui permet d'obtenir des r√©coltes plus abondantes et de meilleure qualit√©.

3 - Les abeilles sont des esp√®ces importantes pour la biodiversit√©. En encourageant leur pr√©sence, vous contribuez √† maintenir l'√©quilibre √©cologique de votre environnement. Elles participent √©galement √† la pollinisation des plantes sauvages, ce qui favorise la diversit√© des √©cosyst√®mes.

4 - En √©t√©, les colonies d'abeilles sont √† leur apog√©e en termes de population et de production de miel. En fournissant un environnement favorable aux abeilles, vous les aidez √† prosp√©rer et √† se d√©velopper, ce qui est crucial pour leur survie √† long terme. Les abeilles sont en effet confront√©es √† de nombreux d√©fis, tels que la diminution des habitats naturels et l'exposition √† des pesticides. Le soutien de leurs populations est essentiel pour pr√©server leur esp√®ce !

5 - Si vous √™tes un apiculteur amateur ou souhaitez vous lancer dans l'apiculture, l'√©t√© est une p√©riode propice pour r√©colter du miel. titre_video: Support Hummingbirds With California Native Plants #nativegardens #hummingbird #californiagardening
description:
Some hummingbird species migrate through California in late January and continue through June. As temperatures drop, many species head south to Mexico, with their journey typically finishing by mid-November. The migration unfolds in stages, with male hummingbirds arriving first to claim territories, followed by females. Historically, their migration has been closely tied to the bloom cycles of their favorite nectar sources. However, climate change is disrupting these cycles, causing key plants like ocotillo to bloom too early, leaving migratory hummingbirds without the food they need.

Planting native plants plays a crucial role in supporting hummingbirds. Native plants not only provide the ideal nectar sources that hummingbirds rely on, but they also bloom at the right times to match the birds' migration patterns. By cultivating plants such as hummingbird sage, monkeyflower, and manzanita, gardeners can create habitats that help sustain hummingbirds through their journey, ensuring that these birds have the nourishment they need, even as climate change alters the natural environment.

The full list of our favorite California native plants that support hummingbirds: https://waterwisegardenplanner.org/lists/bird-and-wildlife-plants/

titre_video: Unique Way to Raise Chickens #farming @RomFarm
description:
Unique Way to Raise Chickens #farming @RomFarm 
Chicken tunnels, a.k.a. "chunnels," are the best way to protect your flock while also letting them roam around your backyard. These tunnels, which can be a straight run or wrap around the perimeter of your property, aren't just good for the birds‚Äîthey're good for your garden, too.

By placing these around your garden beds or crops, these chicken tunnels will encourage your flock to eat weeds and bugs that may wreak havoc on your plants, veggies, and flowers, according to Good Life Permaculture. Set a chicken tunnel up to follow your yard's fence line or your garden's perimeter, and your chickens can double as all-natural weed and bug killers.

titre_video: How Chinese people raise chickens in trees. #chickeneggs #eggfarm #chicken #shorts
description:
How Chinese people raise chickens in trees. #chickeneggs #eggfarm #chicken #lumifarm 
----------------
Free-range chicken farming in the forest is a method used by Chinese farmers that offers health benefits for the chickens by providing them with a wide natural habitat. The chickens are allowed to roam freely, foraging for natural food sources like insects, seeds, and grass, which enhances the quality of their meat.

To protect the eggs and chicks from predators, Chinese farmers have ingeniously created unique chicken nests using plastic containers, which are hung on tree trunks. This solution not only provides a safe space for the chickens to lay their eggs but also shields them from unfavorable weather conditions, allowing for healthy growth and effective reproduction. As a result, farmers can manage their chickens conveniently, making egg collection much easier.

titre_video: Purpusi  The Fight Against Extinction and Mining Threats
description:
Fouquieria is a genus of 11 species of desert flowering plants, the sole genus in the family Fouquieriaceae. ¬† 

Key Characteristics:

Native Range: These plants are native to North America, primarily found in the deserts of the southwestern United States and Mexico. ¬† 
Appearance:
Diverse Forms: They exhibit a wide range of growth forms, from shrubby plants to tall, tree-like species. ¬† 
Spines: Many species have spiny branches, which are modified leaves. ¬† 
Drought Deciduous: They are drought-deciduous, meaning they shed their leaves during dry periods to conserve water. ¬† 
Flowers: Fouquieria species produce showy flowers, often in shades of red, orange, or yellow, which attract pollinators such as hummingbirds and bats. ¬† 
Notable Species:

Ocotillo (Fouquieria splendens): This iconic desert plant is known for its spiny branches and vibrant red flowers. ¬† 
Boojum Tree (Fouquieria columnaris): A unique tree-like species with a tall, slender trunk and a distinctive appearance. ¬† 
Ecological Importance:

Wildlife Habitat: Fouquieria species provide important habitat for a variety of wildlife, including birds, insects, and reptiles.
Erosion Control: Their root systems help to stabilize soils and prevent erosion in desert environments.
Cultivation:

Challenges: Many Fouquieria species are adapted to specific desert conditions and can be challenging to cultivate outside their native habitats.
Requirements: They require well-draining soil, full sun, and minimal water.
If you're interested in learning more about a specific Fouquieria species, I can provide you with more detailed information.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Autonomie : Dans une microferme, chaque ressource est valoris√©e. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Diversification : Contrairement aux monocultures industrielles, les microfermes pratiquent la polyculture et l'agroforesterie. Cela signifie qu'on y trouve une grande vari√©t√© de plantes, d‚Äôarbres et parfois m√™me d‚Äôanimaux. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Circuits courts : Les microfermes favorisent la vente directe aux consommateurs, en cr√©ant des liens de proximit√©. March√©s locaux, ventes √† la ferme ou paniers hebdomadaires, ces circuits courts permettent de r√©duire l'empreinte carbone, de valoriser le travail des producteurs, et de reconnecter les consommateurs avec l‚Äôorigine de leur alimentation. üåçüçáüë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶

titre_video: Processing Garlic for Market: A Large-Scale Operation
description:
The video captures a scene centered around a substantial collection of garlic bulbs, actively being sorted and managed by individuals. This activity suggests preparation for either commercial sale or further processing, indicative of a setting likely situated on a farm or within a bustling market environment. The sheer volume of garlic underscores the agricultural context of the scene.
Beyond its culinary applications, garlic (Allium sativum) is renowned for its numerous health-promoting properties.
Benefits of Garlic:
1. May reduce the risk of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease.
2. Can be used as a dietary supplement to aid in the management of hypertension (high blood pressure).
3. Traditionally employed as a natural remedy for a wide array of health issues.
4. Possesses potent antioxidant properties, contributing to overall cellular health.
5. May have immune-boosting effects, helping the body defend against infections.
Types of Garlic (based on variety):
1. Softneck: Characterized by a soft stalk that can be braided. Includes varieties like California Early and Silverskin.
2. Hardneck: Features a rigid stalk (scape) and generally has a more complex flavor. Includes varieties like Rocambole and Porcelain.
3. Elephant Garlic: Technically a type of leek, it produces very large, mild-flavored cloves.
The careful handling of this significant garlic harvest highlights its economic and medicinal importance within the community.
Summary:
Individuals sort a large garlic pile at a likely farm or market, emphasizing its health benefits and potential for sale or processing.

description:
Easy DIY Newspaper Plant Pots ü™¥ These are eco-friendly, cheap, and simple to make containers for growing seedlings. All you need is non-glossy newsprint and a straight-sided open container.

Once planted up, these pots can last up to a month before they break down. Mold may grow on them during that time, but it won't hurt the seedlings inside. Once they've come to the end of their life, they can be planted directly in the soil or composted.

Also, newspapers are made from tree pulp, and modern newspaper inks are made of soy. Both are safe for plants and your garden.

titre_video: Boost Your Seedlings with Fish Fertilizer: Seed Starting, Transplanting, and Fertilizing Tips!
description:
Welcome to our gardening shorts where we share innovative, natural methods to give your plants the best start! In this video, we explore the benefits of using fish fertilizer to fertilize seedlings, an eco-friendly way to enhance plant growth from seed starting to transplanting and beyond. Discover how this nutrient-rich, organic fertilizer can transform your garden by promoting vigorous root development and lush foliage.

We begin by demonstrating how to properly dilute and apply fish fertilizer during the seed starting phase. This step is crucial to ensure that your delicate seedlings receive the essential nutrients they need without being overwhelmed. As your plants grow, we move on to transplanting techniques that help minimize shock and set the stage for robust growth. By incorporating fish fertilizer during transplanting, you create an ideal environment for your plants to thrive.

Throughout the video, we highlight the importance of consistent fertilizing practices and how natural products like fish fertilizer can replace synthetic alternatives, offering both environmental benefits and improved plant health. Whether you‚Äôre a beginner or an experienced gardener, our step-by-step guide is designed to simplify the process and provide you with practical tips for every stage of your gardening journey.
#SeedStarting #Transplanting #Fertilizing #OrganicGardening #FishFertilizer

titre_video: Mon Jardin d√©di√© √† la "non-m√©thode" de Masanobu Fukuoka. Comment il est avant l'√©t√©?
description:
Je pr√©sente pour la premi√®re fois ma jungle potager √† la mani√®re de Fukuoka*, en bas de mon for√™t jardin tr√®s ombrag√© existe une surface de 400 m2 maximum de ce qui √©tait des graviers et des constructions pour voitures et bestiaux. J'ai compl√®tement chang√© la destination de cet espace...

*Masanobu Fukuoka (Á¶èÂ≤° Ê≠£‰ø°, Fukuoka Masanobu?), n√© le 2 f√©vrier 1913 √† Iyo et mort le 16 ao√ªt 2008, est un agriculteur japonais, connu pour son engagement en faveur de l'agriculture naturelle.

Biographie

Microbiologiste de formation et sp√©cialiste en phytopathologie, il travaille au Bureau des Douanes de Yokohama, √† la Division de l'Inspection des Plantes. Rapidement, il commence √† douter des progr√®s apport√©s par l'agriculture scientifique (d√©pendante du travail de la terre, des engrais et des pesticides chimiques), et d√©missionne alors de son poste. Il d√©cide de retourner sur la ferme de son p√®re, sur l'√Æle de Shikoku. D√®s lors, il consacre sa vie √† d√©velopper une agriculture plus conforme √† ses convictions, qu'il qualifiera d'agriculture naturelle.

Ses recherches, inspir√©es de ses racines culturelles zen, tao√Øste, shinto, bouddhiste, vont dans le sens d'une unification spirituelle entre l'Homme et la Nature. √Ä partir des ann√©es 1980, ses exp√©riences rencontrent progressivement une reconnaissance mondiale, et il multiplie les conf√©rences et les rencontres internationales. Sa ferme devient un lieu d'√©change sur ses pratiques pour les experts et les curieux venus du monde entier.

Il √©crit le livre La R√©volution d'un seul brin de paille, publi√© en 1975 au Japon, qui raconte et th√©orise son exp√©rience en agriculture naturelle.

¬´ ...r√©pandre de la paille... est le fondement de ma m√©thode pour faire pousser le riz et les c√©r√©ales d'hiver. C'est en relation avec tout, avec la fertilit√©, la germination, les mauvaises herbes, la protection contre les moineaux, l'irrigation. Concr√®tement et th√©oriquement, l'utilisation de la paille en agriculture est un point crucial. Il me semble que c'est quelque chose que je ne peux faire comprendre aux gens. ¬ª

¬´ Faire pousser des arbres sans √©lagage, sans fertilisant ni pulv√©risations chimiques n'est possible que dans un environnement naturel. ¬ª

¬´ Comme la nourriture naturelle peut √™tre produite avec le minimum de co√ªt et d'effort, j'en d√©duis qu'elle devrait √™tre vendue meilleur march√©. ¬ª

En laissant faire la nature, et en limitant au maximum les interventions humaines n√©cessaires, il se rend compte que le rendement de sa production de riz est meilleur qu'en agriculture classique. 


M√™me sans apport ext√©rieur, sa m√©thode d'agriculture a pour principal effet d'enrichir le sol plut√¥t que de l'√©puiser.

Selon lui, l'esprit de discrimination, qui frappe l'ensemble de nos soci√©t√©s, a touch√© aussi l'agriculture productiviste moderne, et en explique les d√©rives. L'esprit de non-discrimination permet √† l'homme attach√© √† la nature de la percevoir comme un tout non diff√©rentiable. Le S≈´tra du C≈ìur, qu'il cite, essence du bouddhisme mahayana, r√©sume l'esprit et la pratique de cet ancien chercheur en pathologies des plantes. Sa r√©f√©rence √† Dieu sera plus marqu√©e dans son dernier livre. Son premier ouvrage offre un √©clairage simple et clair sur l'√©volution de l'agriculture japonaise et mondiale.

En 1988 il a re√ßu le prix Ramon Magsaysay pour ses travaux et services rendus √† l'humanit√©.

Beaucoup de travail a √©t√© fait pour adapter la m√©thode Fukuoka aux conditions de l'agriculture europ√©enne, entre autres les recherches des Fran√ßais Marc Bonfils et Claude Bourguignon, le travail d'Emilia Hazelip, qui au cours de nombreux stages en France, en Espagne, et aux √âtats-Unis, ont repris les fondamentaux du travail de Fukuoka.

Inspiration

La philosophie de cette agriculture, faire avec la nature et pas contre elle, entre en forte r√©sonance avec celle de Bill Mollison et David Holmgren, les deux fondateurs du concept de ¬´ permaculture ¬ª ou ¬´ agriculture permanente ¬ª, et cela malgr√© des diff√©rences notables dans la mise en pratique. L'agriculture naturelle, impliquant que l'homme se positionne en tant que serviteur de la nature, reste bas√©e sur le non-agir (pas de produit fertilisant pr√©par√© comme le compost, pas de taille), alors qu'en permaculture ou agriculture permanente, la mise en place d'un zonage am√®ne √† intensifier certaines cultures par des transferts de fertilit√© entre zones (ajout de compost, fumure, arbres fruitiers paliss√©s et taill√©s), l'homme s'y consid√®re comme un ¬´ organisateur ¬ª de la nature.


bibliographie

La R√©volution d'un seul brin de paille : Une introduction √† l'agriculture sauvage, Paris, Guy Tr√©daniel √âditeur, 2005 (1975 au japon, 1985 aux √âtats-unis), 202 p.

La Voie du retour √† la nature : th√©orie et pratique pour une philosophie verte

üå±üî•üåø Biochar: Cultivating Richer Soils for Greener Growth. Instant gold for your soil!‚≠ê
description:
üå±üî•üåø Biochar: Cultivating Richer Soils for Greener Growth. Instant gold for your soil!‚≠ê

üå± Improved Soil Fertility: Biochar's porous structure acts as a habitat for beneficial microorganisms and contains essential nutrients like potassium, calcium, and magnesium. It enhances soil fertility by retaining water and nutrients.

üåø Increased Nutrient Retention: The porous nature of biochar helps prevent nutrient leaching, allowing plants to access nutrients over a longer period, reducing the need for frequent fertilization.

üíß Enhanced Soil Structure: Biochar improves soil structure by increasing aeration and water retention. It creates soil pockets, improving water-holding capacity, particularly in sandy soils.

üåç Carbon Sequestration: Adding biochar to soil can sequester carbon, mitigating climate change by storing carbon in the ground for extended periods.

üîΩ Reduced Greenhouse Gas Emissions: Incorporating biochar into soil can reduce emissions of nitrous oxide, a potent greenhouse gas, by altering soil conditions.

ü¶† Promotion of Microbial Activity: Biochar supports a healthy microbial population in the soil, providing a habitat for beneficial microorganisms that aid plant health.

üå°Ô∏è pH Buffering: Biochar has a neutral pH, which can buffer acidic or alkaline soils, bringing them closer to a neutral level suitable for many plants.

üåæ Reduced Soil Compaction: Adding biochar to the soil can reduce compaction, allowing better root penetration and promoting healthier plant growth.

‚ôªÔ∏è Recycling Agricultural Waste: Using biochar helps recycle agricultural waste that might otherwise be discarded, offering a sustainable and eco-friendly solution.

description:
les pompes centrifuges ne sont pas indiqu√©es pour une utilisation ou le rapport √©nergie fournie/travail obtenu est d√©terminant, comme une installation en autonomie.

Fort peu de gens le savent, c'est bien dommage pour eux, mais d'un autre c√¥t√© cela garantit un march√© de l'occasion assez fourni et √† un prix tr√®s bas !

Il faut s'y conna√Ætre pour choisir une pompe centrifuge, et savoir "lire derri√®re les chiffres" En effet elle va se pr√©senter pour une pression max de 3 bars par exemple, et pour un d√©bit max de 4000 litres heure. Une sacr√©e performance ! sauf que cela signifie 3 bars √† un d√©bit ridicule voire nul, et les 4000 litres ils sont sans  d√©pression c√¥t√© aspiration ni perte de charge, mais pour Z√©ro pression fournie ! 
ce sont des pompes qui fournissent la pression OU le d√©bit, et entre les deux elles ont une courbe sp√©cifique. Une pompe centrifuge tire son travail de la centrifugation du liquide, ce qui induit √©videmment beaucoup de friction. Or la friction est TRES energivore, elle conduit rapidement √† l'√©chauffement d'ailleurs.

TRES energivore est synonyme de "incompatible avec une installation en autonomie √©nerg√©tique" 

ce mod√®le de pompe a √©t√© cr√©e en 1930. Il est toujours fabriqu√© de nos jours mais son prix est √† la hauteur de sa qualit√©, increvable. Piston √† double effet en cuir. Chemise cuivre, 4 soupapes, vilbrequin, paliers graiss√©s √†l'huile (niveau d'huile avec jauge)
son moteur original est √† paliers et non pas roulements. Il est increvable et son fonctionnement est tr√®s silencieux (hormis si vous laissez la courroie d√©tendue comme c'est mon cas, cette courroie a 30 ans) cette pompe que vous voyez a √©t√© utilis√©e des dizaines d'ann√©es (entre 40 et 50 ans) en tant que pompe d'arrosage, je n'ai chang√© que quelques pi√®ces d'usure.

vous pouvez remarquer qu'elle d√©marre avec une rare douceur. Cette pompe triphas√©e fonctionne sur batteries, au travers d'un onduleur victron multiplus 3KVA monophas√©, et elle est conduire par un variateur Atlivar 11, accessoirement 2,2KW ce qui n'a pas d'importance. Ce type de pompe fournit √† la fois le volume donn√© ET la pression max √©ventuellement (ici 4 bars)
ce montage, en fait ce moteur a √©t√© rebobin√© par mes soins, au travers du variateur mono/tri consomme 400 W lorsque la pompe d√©marre √† env 2,5Bars et 600 W juste avant la coupure lorsque la pression s'est √©lev√©e √† 4 bars.

Elle m√©riterait un bon nettoyage, je ne vous le fais pas dire. Elle le m√©rite, elle en aura, mais pour l'instant, √ßa ne l'emp√™che pas de travailler.

Surtout ne jamais oublier de huiler avec de l'huile de TRES BONNE qualit√© le moteur, les deux paliers, et SURTOUT celui du c√¥t√© courroie. Vous ne voyez pas par o√π ? il faut peut √™tre faire sauter un petit bouchon en plastique devenu cassant, cassez  le, la vie de votre pompe en d√©pend car s'il y a un entretien √† faire c'est bien celui l√†. Et l'huile du vilbrequin doit √™tre chang√©e tous les ans, m√™me si elle para√Æt toujours comme neuve (ce qui est le cas m√™me apr√®s des ann√©es) mais faites-le, car l'huile aspire l'eau un peu et avec le temps  tuerait ses paliers normalement INCREVABLES

titre_video: Mushroom ASMR: Fly Agaric (Amanita muscaria) and King Bolete (Boletus edulis), indicator species
description:
The fly agaric (Amanita muscaria) and King Bolete aka porcini (Boletus edulis) are often found growing near each other in the same habitat and season. The fly agaric is mildly toxic, but can be boiled in water several times to remove the toxins. King boletes are delicious sweet nutty meaty mushrooms, one of my favorites.
.
Amanita muscaria is a common mycorrhizal mushroom that grows worldwide (thanks to the timber industry). It is toxic, trippy, and edible depending on how it is processed. Unlike deadly Amanitas (Death Cap/Destroying Angel), muscaria does not contain amatoxins. Instead, it contains ibotenic acid which is a potent neurotoxin and muscimol which can exert entheogenic (mind altering) effects. Ibotenic acid can be chemically converted (decarboxylated) into muscimol using heat and low pH (no need to drink pee). Dried muscaria can be brewed into a tea to access the entheogenic properties of muscimol.
.
Sami shamans did use Amanita muscaria for rituals, but that‚Äôs where any actual evidence for this mushroom being associated with Christmas ends. Theresa red and white motifs of Santa Claus came about from Coca-Kola ads in the 30s. Given that muscaria can act as a dissociative sedative, I think it‚Äôs highly unlikely that Vikings ate this mushroom before battle, more likely that consumed henbane.
.
#mushrooms #mycology #mushroomasmr #amanitamuscaria #boletusedulis #porcini

titre_video: Exploring the Fabulous Fungi: A Journey Through Mushroom Diversity #mushrooms #nature ytshort
description:
Mushrooms are some of the most diverse and intriguing organisms on Earth! In this video, we explore various unique fungi, each with its own distinct shape, color, and habitat.

üåø Featured Mushrooms in This Video:
üçÑ Mushroom 1 (Top Left) ‚Äì A red-capped mushroom with gills, possibly from the Agaricus or Lepiota family, often found growing on decomposing organic matter.
üçÑ Mushroom 2 (Top Right) ‚Äì A strange, textured white mushroom with a dark, elongated stem, resembling a species of Ganoderma or another wood-inhabiting fungus.
üçÑ Mushroom 3 (Bottom Left) ‚Äì A white-stemmed mushroom with dark gills, growing in moist soil, potentially a type of Agaricus.
üçÑ Mushroom 4 (Bottom Middle) ‚Äì A large, tan mushroom with a smooth cap, which could belong to the Pluteus or Russula family.
üçÑ Mushroom 5 (Bottom Right) ‚Äì A small, white-capped mushroom with a textured surface, possibly an immature Amanita species.

Join us as we uncover the beauty and mystery of these fungi! Some mushrooms are edible, while others can be toxic or even bioluminescent. Always admire them in the wild but be cautious before handling or consuming any wild fungi.

üîî Subscribe for more nature discoveries, and let us know in the comments which mushroom fascinated you the most!

titre_video: California Desert Protection - Seed by Seed in Beautiful Joshua Tree #desert #mdlt #mbconservation
description:
See full video @morongobasinconservation 
With an estimated two in five of Earth‚Äôs wild native plant species at risk of extinction, seed banks worldwide work to stave off a rapidly diminishing biodiversity. In this region, the desert ecosystem suffers from significant drought, increasingly severe weather due to climate change, and shrinkage due to man‚Äôs relentless encroachment.
In an architecturally well-known adobe building deep in the Mojave Desert on the outskirts of dusty Joshua Tree, California, more than five million seeds quietly rest. Carefully secured within neat rows of jars, they chill inside a specialty refrigeration unit. 
Despite its unassuming interior, the Mojave Desert Seed Bank is achieving the lofty goal of being an insurance policy for the flora of the Mojave and Colorado deserts. 
Seeds from the Mojave Desert Land Trust‚Äôs 26-million-acre service region have been collected, processed by volunteers, and safely maintained here.  These seeds from the Mojave Desert Seed Bank are used for research, habitat restoration, and long-term species conservation. 
#mbconservation #Mojavedesertlandtrust #protectcadeserts #seedbank #jbwd #nativeplants #mojavewateragency  #29palmswater #sanmanuelbandofmissionindians #mojavedesert #joshuatree #29 Palms #YuccaValley #Pioneertown #pipescanyon #seedsaving #JTNP  #mojavenationalpreserve #coloradodesert #morongovalley #morongobasin #desert #desertgardening #gardening #gardeningvideos #palmsprings #indio #goldenstatewater #jbwd

titre_video: Seed by Seed - Saving California Deserts #joshuatree #mdlt #morongobasinconservation
description:
The Mojave Desert Land Trust in Joshua Tree is protecting California deserts -- seed by seed! Seed banks are a tool for the conservation and understanding of wild plant populations. Saving seeds also serves as an insurance policy against extinction. 
Desert ecosystems make up approximately one quarter of California and suffer from significant drought, severe weather, and precipitous loss of habitat and wildlife. Seeds from the Mojave Desert Seed Bank are used to restore habitat, for research, and for the conservation of species.

titre_video: LIFE Habitat | Sierra Space Successfully Completes Month Long Creep Test
description:
Sierra Space has successfully performed a month-long Accelerated Systematic Creep (ASC) test on LIFE ‚Äì the first milestone in its 2023 testing campaign. 

Engineers loaded a one-third-scale version of the inflatable habitat with a sustained amount of pressure over an extended period until it failed. 

The campaign demonstrated that the LIFE habitat pressure shell design has a predicted life of far greater than 60 years ‚Äì or 525,600 hours ‚Äì based on Sierra Space‚Äôs 15-year on-orbit life requirement and the applied 4x safety factor.

The next series of one-third-scale LIFE certification tests will focus on inserting hard structures into the pressure shell and correlating the results to previous tests. Sierra Space anticipates moving toward full-scale LIFE habitat tests later this year.

Thanks to a recently signed Space Act Agreement with NASA, Sierra Space will expand its collaborative environment with Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC), in Huntsville, Ala., to continue critical work on LIFE. Alabama is the seventh location across the nation where Sierra Space operates facilities, joining Colorado, Florida, North Carolina, Texas, Wisconsin and Washington, D.C.

Press Release: https://www.sierraspace.com/newsroom/press-releases/sierra-space-advances-future-of-space-habitation-in-low-earth-orbit-and-deep-space-with-life-test

titre_video: Reviving Lake Ecosystems: Nanobubbles and Nutrient Reduction
description:
Nanobubbles have the ability to improve sequestration of nitrogen and phosphorus in lakes. This is important because having too much of these nutrients can lead to a problem.

When there's an excess of nutrients, water quality is reduced and problems like excessive algae and muck increase. In addition to removing oxygen from the water, this overgrowth can harm fish and other aquatic creatures.

This whole situation is called eutrophication, and it can seriously harm the balance of entire ecosystems.

titre_video: Can We Grow Food on The Moon?
description:
Scientists are exploring the possibility of growing food on the Moon, and one company is leading the way.

Solsys Mining in Norway has been studying the lunar regolith, the layer of loose rock and dust covering the Moon's surface, and they have discovered that it contains many valuable plant nutrients. By developing systems to extract these nutrients for use in hydroponic agriculture, the company believes that growing food on the Moon is possible.

But why hydroponics? Lunar soil compacts in the presence of water, creating difficulties for plant germination and root growth. Hydroponics, the technique of growing plants using a water-based nutrient solution rather than soil, offers a practical alternative for lunar farming.

This breakthrough could be a game-changer for future long-term lunar missions, as growing plants for food and oxygen will be critical. Who knows? Maybe one day we'll be enjoying Moon-grown lettuce in our space salads!

Subscribe to Science Time: https://www.youtube.com/sciencetime24

#science #shorts #space

titre_video: They don't want to be wrong.  #regenerativeagriculture #farmer #farmers
description:
Richard Teague, PhD, (retired) Professor of Grazing Ecosystems Ecology @tamu, works to understand grazing practices, and how pasture forage production and nutrient quality is affected by different grazing methods.

Teague: ‚ÄúIf you do a small plot experiment on a couple of meters by a couple of meters, that‚Äôll tell you something about that that‚Äôs going to be accurate. But what does that mean to the whole farming unit? That‚Äôs what‚Äôs missing in the world today. We‚Äôre producing papers and papers and papers about smaller and smaller things.‚Äù

Byck: ‚ÄúSo, the science isn‚Äôt replicating nature.‚Äù

And that‚Äôs the problem! Farmers spend thousands and thousands each year fighting with nature, because that‚Äôs what they‚Äôve been conditioned to think is necessary. We‚Äôre here to conduct rigorous, large scale science to prove that working WITH nature is the best way for farmers to save time and money. Soil health creates farmer wealth.

Interested in arranging a screening of Roots So Deep for your town?

Let us know at info@rootssodeep.org

titre_video: Top experts discuss regenerative agriculture and resilient communities #shorts
description:
In June, the second annual Old Salt Festival brought over 2,000 people to Helmville, Montana, for a rocking celebration of land stewardship through food and music, community and dialog.

The event brought together for the first time thought leaders Dr. Fred Provenza (professor emeritus of Animal Science at Utah State University, and prolific author, most recently of Nourishment: What Animals Can Teach Us About Rediscovering our Nutritional Wisdom, 2018), Nicole Masters (agroecologist and author of For the Love of Soil: Strategies to Regenerate our Food Production Systems, 2019) and Kate Geagan (director of strategy for FoodAndPlanet.org, dietician and author of Go Green Get Lean: Trim Your Waistline with the Ultimate Low-Carbon Footprint Diet, 2009). 

With moderator Linda Poole of Western Landowners Alliance, the panel addressed the powerful ‚Äúwhy‚Äù, and complex ‚Äúhow‚Äù, of raising nutrient dense foods on whole and healthy working lands. 

https://onland.westernlandowners.org/2024/voices/were-inside-and-its-holding-us-nutrient-cycles-for-people-and-planet-with-fred-provenza-nicole-masters-and-kate-geagan/

titre_video: Corn Harvesting - Good Tools and Machinery Make the Job Easy
SILAGE MAKING. 100% Success #Goat #Sheep #cattle #Agriculture
Harvest scallions
description:
The automatic scallion harvester has the following benefits and advantages:
 
- Improve harvesting efficiency: Compared with manual harvesting, the automatic scallion harvester can quickly complete a series of processes such as digging, conveying, and cleaning. It can harvest a large quantity of scallions in a short period of time, greatly shortening the harvesting cycle, and is especially suitable for farmers and farms with large-scale scallion plantations.
 
- Reduce labor intensity: Manual harvesting of scallions requires long hours of bending over, digging, and carrying, which is extremely labor-intensive. However, the automatic scallion harvester can achieve mechanized operation, and the operator only needs to control the equipment in the cab, greatly reducing physical labor.
 
- Reduce damage to scallions: Professional automatic scallion harvesters are equipped with reasonable digging and conveying devices. They can operate according to the growth characteristics of scallions and soil conditions, effectively avoiding damage to scallions caused by improper force or unreasonable use of tools during manual harvesting, and improving the commercial rate of scallions.
 
- Stable harvesting quality: The operating parameters of the automatic scallion harvester can be precisely adjusted, such as digging depth and conveying speed. It can ensure relatively consistent harvesting quality under different field and soil conditions, so that the soil at the roots of the harvested scallions is cleaned thoroughly and the scallions are neatly arranged, facilitating subsequent sorting and transportation.
 
- Save costs: In the long run, although there is a certain initial investment required to purchase an automatic scallion harvester, it can reduce the dependence on labor and lower labor costs. Moreover, the high efficiency of mechanized operation allows scallions to be harvested and put on the market in a timely manner, avoiding losses caused by untimely harvesting, thus improving the planting efficiency.
