titre_video: Amazing gourd fishing technique #fishing #fish #amazingfish #bigfish #viralvideo #fishingtrip
description:
Gourd fishing is an ancient yet ingenious technique used in various cultures, particularly in Asia and Africa. This method utilizes hollowed-out gourds or calabashes to trap fish efficiently without the need for modern equipment. Fishermen carefully prepare the gourds by cutting small openings and sometimes weighting them to ensure they float at the desired depth.

The process begins with placing the gourds in the water, where they mimic natural debris or floating food. Small fish, seeking shelter, swim into the gourds' openings. Once inside, they become trapped, as their natural instinct is to move forward rather than retreat. In some variations, bait is placed inside to attract fish faster. Fishermen then periodically check the gourds and collect the trapped fish by simply lifting them from the water.

One of the greatest advantages of this technique is its sustainability. Unlike nets or spears, gourd fishing minimizes damage to fish populations and does not disrupt aquatic ecosystems. It is a low-cost, eco-friendly practice that has been passed down through generations, proving its effectiveness.

In some regions, this technique is used for catching specific fish species, such as catfish or tilapia, which naturally seek shelter in enclosed spaces. Additionally, some fishermen enhance their success by strategically positioning gourds near riverbanks or shallow waters where fish activity is high.

The simplicity and efficiency of gourd fishing make it a remarkable example of traditional fishing ingenuity. It showcases how humans have adapted natural materials to harvest food while maintaining harmony with the environment.

#GourdFishing #FishingTechniques #TraditionalFishing #EcoFishing #SustainableFishing #AncientFishing #FishingLife #SurvivalFishing #HandmadeFishing #FishingGear #RiverFishing #NatureFishing #FishingTips #PrimitiveFishing #FishingMethods #FishingInnovation #WildFishing #FishTrap #FishingCommunity #FishingSecrets #FishingDIY #HandmadeTrap #FishingTricks #CulturalFishing #FishingTradition

Au cours de cette digestion, l'amidon est transform√© en glucose, les prot√©ines sont fragment√©es en acides amin√©s, et les lipides en acides gras et glyc√©rol. Ces nutriments, ou mol√©cules assimilables par l'organisme, sont alors absorb√©s par le sang ou la lymphe. Ils permettent ainsi de renouveler les cellules et de fournir de l'√©nergie √† l'organisme.

titre_video: EASIEST WAY TO DEHYDRATE BANANAS HOW TO MAKE BANANA CHIPS USE FOR RIPE BANANAS DEHYDRATED CHIP
description:
Lots of videos on YouTube with use for ripe fruit and dehydrating fruit. How to make chewy bananas CHIPS fast and easiest lengthwise. How to Dehydrate Vegetables video. Fastest DIY hacks for dehydration of Bananas and other fruits. Dehydrator comparison videos. Instructions on exactly how to make fruit silicon tray covers. This was my FIRST video ten years ago, I have learned since then. 

I do not add anything or treat the bananas in any way. DEHYDRATE AT 130 DEGREES FOR 12 HOURS, FLIP AND DRY until your desired texture. 

Link to post on making dried bananas into BABY FOOD: http://thesecretisgratitude.blogspot.com/2015/05/making-baby-food-from-dehydrated-fruits.html

Link to post on making BANANA FLOUR WAFFLES: http://thesecretisgratitude.blogspot.com/2012/04/banana-flour-nutmeg-and-yogurt-waffles.html

Link to DEHYDRATED BANANA PEELS and health: http://thesecretisgratitude.blogspot.com/2018/08/dehydrating-banana-peels-nutrition.html

If you are NEW TO DEHYDRATING, here is a basic on "how to" keep bugs out etc.: http://thesecretisgratitude.blogspot.com/2010/04/dehydrating-fruits-and-veggies.html

Written instructions are on my blog: https://thesecretisgratitude.com Type in "dehydrator bananas" into the search box at the bottom of the home page to find the posts on this.


¬†I have been dehydrating for over 25 years. I tried making dehydrated bananas into chips only once, and it wasn't fast. After that, I started to dehydrate them the long way and make it easier so everyone enjoys them, and only having to turn 4 pieces rather than 20 chip per banana. YOU CAN MAKE THEM CRISPY OR chewy. If you have any questions, feel free to ask on my blog or comment below.
Written instructions are on my blog: https://thesecretisgratitude.com Type in "dehydrator bananas" into the search box at the bottom of the home page to find the posts on this.

Thanks for watching and have a blessed day!

titre_video: Explore Mesa Garden  The Cactus Haven by Steve Brack
description:
Desert plants are a fascinating group of organisms that have evolved remarkable adaptations to survive in some of the harshest environments on Earth. Here's an overview:

Key Characteristics:

Water Conservation: This is the primary challenge and the focus of most adaptations.

Reduced Water Loss:
Waxy Coatings: Many desert plants have thick, waxy cuticles on their leaves and stems, minimizing water loss through transpiration (evaporation).
Spines: These structures, often mistaken for leaves, reduce surface area and deter herbivores, further minimizing water loss.
Leaf Modifications: Some plants have reduced or modified leaves (like spines or scales) to minimize water loss.
Water Storage:
Succulence: Succulent plants, like cacti, store water in their fleshy tissues (stems, leaves, or roots). 
Deep Roots: Many desert plants have extensive root systems that tap into deep groundwater sources. Some also have shallow, widespread roots to capture rainwater quickly.
Heat Tolerance:

Shade: Some plants have spines or hairs that provide shade, cooling the plant.
Orientation: Many desert plants orient themselves to minimize sun exposure during the hottest parts of the day.
Drought Tolerance:

Dormancy: Many desert plants enter a dormant state during dry periods, conserving energy and reducing water loss.
Rapid Growth: Some plants have short life cycles, germinating quickly after rain and completing their life cycle before the dry season returns.
Examples of Desert Plants:

Cacti: Iconic desert plants with diverse shapes and sizes, known for their water-storing abilities.
Succulents: A broader category including plants like agave, aloe vera, and jade plants.
Joshua Trees: Unique trees with spiky leaves that are well-adapted to the Mojave Desert.
Creosote Bush: A highly drought-tolerant shrub that dominates many desert landscapes.
Ecological Importance:

Food Web: Desert plants provide food and shelter for a variety of animals, including insects, reptiles, birds, and mammals.
Soil Stabilization: Their root systems help to prevent soil erosion.
Carbon Sequestration: Desert plants play a role in carbon cycling by capturing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
In Summary:

Desert plants are a testament to the incredible diversity and resilience of life. Their unique adaptations allow them to thrive in challenging environments, showcasing the power of natural selection.

Note: This is a general overview. The specific adaptations of desert plants vary greatly depending on the type of desert and the specific environmental conditions.

titre_video: Banana Bunch Cutting Technique with a Special Knife ‚Äì Fast & Efficient Process
description:
Banana Bunch Cutting Technique with a Special Knife ‚Äì Fast & Efficient Process

The banana harvesting process begins by cutting the bunch from its stalk using a special knife. This tool is designed to make cutting easier without damaging the fruit, ensuring the bananas remain in good condition until they are ready for distribution. Proper cutting techniques are essential to keep the plant healthy and allow it to produce new fruit.

‚úÖ Interesting Facts about Banana Harvesting:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Each tree bears fruit only once ‚Äì After harvesting, the main stem dies and is replaced by a new shoot.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Bananas are harvested while still green ‚Äì This prevents damage during transport and extends shelf life.
3Ô∏è‚É£ A single bunch can weigh dozens of kilograms ‚Äì Proper technique is needed to lower it safely.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Banana trees don‚Äôt have true wooden trunks ‚Äì Their structure consists of tightly wrapped leaf sheaths.

‚úÖ Advantages of Using a Special Knife for Harvesting:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Easier cutting process ‚Äì A sharp and strong knife speeds up the work.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Prevents fruit damage ‚Äì Proper technique keeps the bananas intact and fresh.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Maintains farm productivity ‚Äì Correct cutting ensures healthy plant regeneration.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Safer for workers ‚Äì Reduces the risk of injury during harvesting.

üìå Additional Education:
After harvesting, bananas are usually left to ripen naturally or placed in a controlled environment to accelerate the process. Their skin changes from green to yellow as the sugar content increases.

titre_video: Making organic cold pressed olive oil in Italy.
description:
I love cold-pressed virgin olive oil! It's my go-to oil in all of my recipes because it's healthy and delicious.  As a promoter of the Mediterranean diet and a lover of natural ingredients, I was so happy to spend a day being part of the entire process at an organic farm in Southern Italy from picking to bottling.

The reason why cold-pressed olive oil is better is because its extracted from fresh olives using a mechanical process, rather than chemical extraction like many other oils use. 

The process of making cold-pressed olive oil in Italy involves several steps:

Harvesting: The olives are carefully harvested by hand or by shaking the tree branches, usually between late October and early December, when the olives are at their peak ripeness.

Sorting and washing: The olives are sorted to remove leaves, twigs, or other debris, and then washed to remove dirt and other impurities.

Grinding: The olives are then crushed into a paste using a mill or crusher. Traditionally, this was done using large granite or stone wheels that were turned by animal power, but today, modern mills use stainless steel blades or hammers to crush the olives.

Malaxation: The olive paste is then stirred slowly to allow the oil droplets to separate and coalesce, a process called malaxation.

Separation: The oil is then separated from the paste using a press, which applies pressure to the paste to extract the oil. Traditionally, this was done using a hydraulic press, but today, modern centrifuges are used to separate the oil from the paste.

Filtration: The oil is then filtered to remove any remaining impurities and sediment.

Storage: The finished oil is stored in stainless steel or dark glass containers to protect it from light and air.

I learned so much on this behind-the-scenes tour. If you're interested in buying some delicious extra virgin cold-pressed Italian olive oil it's important to note that in order for an olive oil to be labeled as "extra-virgin" in Italy, it must meet strict quality standards, including having an acidity level of less than 0.8% and passing a taste test by a panel of experts. This ensures that only the highest-quality oils are labeled as extra-virgin.

For delicious recipes or for into to join my upcoming culinary retreats in Italy where you can make cold-pressed olive oil then please visit my website https://www.harvestandwellness.com/

titre_video: ECOKRAFT - Fermentation residues & cocoa shells to energy pellets
description:
Fermentation residues and cocoa shells can be converted into energy pellets, which are a more convenient and versatile form of fuel than loose materials. Energy pellets are typically made by compressing the materials into small, dense pellets using a pellet mill. The pellets can then be used for a variety of applications, such as heating buildings or generating electricity.

There are several advantages to converting fermentation residues and cocoa shells to energy pellets:

1. Efficient use of waste materials: By converting fermentation residues and cocoa shells to energy pellets, waste materials can be put to productive use instead of being discarded or causing environmental problems.

2. Renewable energy source: Energy pellets made from fermentation residues and cocoa shells are a renewable energy source that can be produced on an ongoing basis. This reduces the reliance on non-renewable energy sources such as fossil fuels.

3. Lower greenhouse gas emissions: Energy pellets made from fermentation residues and cocoa shells have lower greenhouse gas emissions than traditional fossil fuels. This can help to reduce the overall carbon footprint of energy production.

4. Cost-effective: Energy pellets made from fermentation residues and cocoa shells can be a cost-effective fuel source, particularly if the materials are readily available and inexpensive.

5. Versatile: Energy pellets made from fermentation residues and cocoa shells can be used in a variety of applications, such as heating buildings, generating electricity, and fueling industrial processes.

Overall, converting fermentation residues and cocoa shells to energy pellets can be an environmentally friendly and cost-effective way to produce renewable energy. It can also help to 
reduce waste and greenhouse gas emissions.

titre_video: Splitting Firewood by Hand with an Axe | Traditional Wood Cutting Technique
description:
In this satisfying, silent video, you'll watch the traditional method of splitting firewood by hand using nothing more than an axe and muscle. Even though the video has no narration, this description explains the full process and purpose of manual wood cutting ‚Äî a time-honored skill for anyone living off the land, homesteading, or preparing for winter.

Splitting wood is more than just brute force ‚Äî it requires technique, timing, and understanding the grain of the log. It‚Äôs an essential part of rural living and survival, especially in areas where wood is used for heating, cooking, or building.

üìå What You‚Äôll See in This Video:

Positioning logs upright on a sturdy chopping block
Using a full-sized axe to split firewood cleanly
Striking at the natural cracks or center of the wood grain
Watching logs split apart with precision and efficiency
Repeating the process with both small and large pieces
üìå Why Manual Wood Splitting Still Matters:

A key survival and homestead skill
Helps reduce dependency on power tools or fuel-based machines
Builds strength, coordination, and respect for traditional labor
Offers a sustainable, eco-friendly method of preparing firewood
This video is perfect for those interested in bushcraft, off-grid living, rural life, or traditional skills. It‚Äôs also surprisingly therapeutic and satisfying to watch ‚Äî seeing each log crack open with a well-placed swing never gets old.

üëç Like and subscribe for more real-world skills, traditional labor videos, and unspoken demonstrations of timeless techniques.

titre_video: Eco-worthy 10Watts Portable Solar Trickle Charger for 12V Batteries in Car & Boat
description: ECO-WORTHY 10W Portable Solar Trickle Charger perfect trickle charger/maintainer for 12V batteries of cars, motorcycles, boats, snowmobiles, tractors etc. Comes with the cigarette lighter adapter, 1 pair of battery clips and 4 pieces of PVC suckers. Unique design-high quality clips to prevent short circuit. Charging 12V battery in emergency, suitable for the vehicles in outdoor work, travel or camping training, and the vehicles are put for a long time. Easy to install and completely maintenance-free. Environmental protection and energy saving, built-in blocking diode to prevent reverse discharge, not only maintains the battery lifetime but also extends its usage life, keep the battery from drain dead. Please note that the protective plastic film on the panel surface is supposed to peel off. The cigarette plug option only works if it has constant power when the key is out of the ignition. When you start the car, please remove the solar panel from the car battery.
